q1.question:
According to legend, Horatio Nelson’s body was stored in this substance after the Battle of
Trafalgar. This product was created as a way to dispose of the molasses created as a byproduct of
the manufacture of sugar in the Caribbean. In the British Navy, Edward Vernon created the
practice of diluting this substance with water. For 10 points, name this component of grog.
(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) What Russian tsar freed the serfs in 1861 and was assassinated twenty years later?

This leader forcibly dismissed the Rump Parliament and replaced it with Barebone’s
parliament. He was hated in Ireland for atrocities committed at Wexford and Drogheda. He
helped win the Battle of Naseby as a cavalry commander in the New Model Army. For 10 points,
name this man who served as Lord Protector of England in the interregnum following the
execution of Charles I of England.

Nobility serving under this dynasty followed the "Table of Ranks" to determine bureaucratic
advancement. This royal house came to power after three different "False Dmitris" were
suppressed during the Time of Troubles. For 10 points, name this house founded by Mikhail I in
1613, which remained in control of Russia until the twentieth century.

This king ordered the destruction of all remaining Protestant churches in the Edict of
Fontainebleau (pr. FAHN-tohn-blow). He was opposed at his accession by the Fronde
movement, which was countered by his early advisor, Cardinal Mazarin. For 10 points, name this
monarch who reigned for seventy-two years as the absolutist "Sun King" of France.

This party was victimized by the Zinoviev letter hoax, which purported to show Soviet control
of its operations and brought down its first prime minister, Ramsay Macdonald. This party was
first represented in Parliament by Scottish coal miner Keir Hardie. For 10 points, name this
party, now the more left-wing of the two largest political parties in the United Kingdom.

In the autumn of 1649, this man led armies which sacked Drogheda (pr. DRAH-huh-dah),
leading to his reputation as a cruel conqueror of Ireland. He was succeeded by his son Richard
after his death. For 10 points, name this leader of the New Model Army who attained supreme
power as "Lord Protector of England" after the Civil War.

(TIEBREAKER BONUS EXAMPLE) What President of Germany, who appointed Hitler Chancellor in 1933, was the
namesake of a zeppelin that caught fire above New Jersey in 1937?

Near the end of this decade, the Mayerling scandal erupted. During this decade, Chinese Gordon
was killed fighting the Mahdi in Sudan. The rules for colonialism were set out at the Berlin
Conference during this decade. For 10 points, identify this decade in which Queen Victoria
celebrated the Golden Jubilee of her 1837 accession to the throne.

(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) What city defeated Genoa (in the Chioggia (pr. kee-OH-juh) War and grew into a great
maritime power under the leadership of "doges?"

In the nineteenth century, this country experienced the Liberal Triennium. An attempt to
enforce the Salic Law in this country sparked the first Carlist War. This country lost nearly all of
its overseas colonies during the early nineteenth century following the rise of Jose de San Martin
and Miguel Hidalgo. For 10 points, name this onetime master of much of Latin America.

This modern-day country was outraged by the Council of Blood being imposed as its ruler, as
well as by the Tenth Penny tax. It allied with the "Sea Beggars" against Spanish governors such
as the Duke of Alba and won its independence in the Eighty Years War. For 10 points, name this
country where William the Silent reigned over land reclaimed from the sea via dikes.

This woman was implicated in a fraud known as the Affair of the Diamond Necklace. She
became known as "the widow Capet" following the death of her husband, Louis XVI. For 10
points, name this queen of France who legendarily dismissed a crowd of peasants crying out for
bread by saying "let them eat cake."

This military leader was declared a martyr by Pope Callixtus III, a generation after this saint's
capture at Compiègne (pr. cahmp-YEN-yuh). Pierre Cauchon (pr. COO-shun) led the court
which condemned her to be burned at the stake in 1431 following her relief of the siege of
Orléans (pr. OH-lee-ahn). For 10 points, name this teenage French patriot of the Hundred Years
War.

(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) The "July Theses" defined the Communist regime of what Eastern European country,
whose Ploiești (pr. ploy-ESH-tuh) oil fields were targeted by Operation Tidal Wave?

This person was appointed as the head of an expedition to Scutari (pr. scoo-TAH-ree) by
war minister Sidney Herbert, who knew of her efforts to improve sanitation. She became known
as the "Lady with the Lamp" for her efforts during the Crimean War. For 10 points, name this
1850s British woman, the founder of modern nursing.

When it became apparent that this event had failed, a disgusted Erich Ludendorff simply
walked away, leading its main organizer to be sentenced to the Landsberg, where Mein Kampf
was written. For 10 points, name this failed 1923 attempt by Adolf Hitler to seize power in
Germany by leading an uprising at a Munich drinking venue.

This man said he planned to use a Kärcher pressure-washer to "clean out" suburbs. In 2014,
this former leader of the UMP was questioned by police for alleged corruption in a judicial
appointment in Monaco. He lost a close re-election bid in 2012 to his left-wing rival François
Hollande (pr. frah-SWAH oh-LAHND). For 10 points, name this former President of France.

(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) The "condottiere" (pr. cahn-DOE-tee-AIR-ee) were what type of soldiers, who fought
most of the wars of Renaissance Italy and were often of English origin and whose use was
warned against by Machiavelli?

The process of creating these places was paused after the article "Dizzy From Success." The
attempt to bring the entire countryside into these places resulted in the Holodomor and other
episodes of famine, as well as direct killings of alleged "kulaks." For 10 points, the First Five Year Plan was aimed at transforming all Soviet agriculture into what socialist institutions?

A powerful advisor based in this city uncovered the Tavora (tuh-VORE-uh) Conspiracy. This
city, where the Marquis of Pombal came to power, was the location of a 1755 disaster that
inspired philosophers across Europe to ask how God could allow large-scale death. For 10
points, name this city that was devastated by a large earthquake described in Candide.

This ship never fought a major battle, as it was under upgrades during Jutland (YUT-land).
This ship was designed at the behest of First Sea Lord Jacky Fisher and targeted in a namesake
"hoax" by Virginia Woolf, who pretended to be an Ethiopian princess. For 10 points, name this
ship whose construction spurred a battleship "arms race" in the decade before World War I.

During this event, the preacher John Ball posed the riddle “When Adam delve and Eve span,
who was then the gentleman?” This event ended shortly after William Walworth, the mayor of
London, beheaded its leader. This event targeted Richard II and protested the 1380 poll tax. For
10 points, name this 1381 uprising in England led by Wat Tyler among a class of people.

(TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) Todor Zhivkov was the longtime Communist dictator of what Eastern European
country, which used ricin pellets fired out of a modified umbrella to assassinate dissidents, and
roughly corresponds to ancient Thrace?

This man advocated for a “priesthood of all believers” in the work To the Christian Nobility of the
German Nation. He was protected by Frederick the Wise after Charles V ordered his arrest. Pope Leo X
excommunicated this man with the bull Exsurge Domine [EX-ur-gay DOE-mee-nay] after he posted the
95 Theses. For ten points, name this German priest who began the Protestant Reformation.

This ruler attempted to establish the Kingdom of Livonia as a vassal state, and this ruler established
his country’s first printing press at Kitai-gorod. This ruler conquered Kazan and Astrakhan, and he
established a secret police force known as the Oprichniki. Feodor I succeeded this ruler after he killed his
eldest son in a fit of rage, eventually leading to the Time of Troubles. For ten points, name this first Tsar
of Russia whose epithet notes his power, not his cruelty.

(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) The War of Jenkins’ Ear was part of what larger conflict over succession to a European
throne?

This family’s crest pictures a red cow eating grass against a yellow background. One member of this
family hosted an orgy in the Banquet of the Chestnuts. That man, the enemy of Girolamo Savonarola,
had formed the League of Venice to oppose Charles VIII’s invasion of Italy. That man’s son had embarked
on the Romagna campaign, and was the inspiration for Niccolo Machiavelli’s The Prince. For ten points,
name this Italian family whose members included Cesare and Pope Alexander VI.

The aftermath of this event led to the creation of the Quadruple Alliance and the formation of the 38
state German Confederation. It restored the Bourbon Dynasty in France with Louis XVIII. This meeting
was interrupted by the Hundred Days and it was headed by Austrian minister Klemens von Metternich.
For ten points, name this 1815 meeting that sought to organize post-Napoleonic Europe.

This woman defeated the Emirate of Granada, ending the Reconquista period of her country. She
sponsored the trips of an explorer from Genoa who started Spanish colonization of the New World. For
ten points, name this Castilian queen who married Ferdinand II of Aragon and sponsored the trips of
Christopher Columbus.

This man gave the Appeal of 18 June Speech during one war. This leader’s opposition to the European
Commission led to the Empty Chair Crisis. He was later criticized after Expo 67 for proclaiming “Long
live free Quebec!” This man’s government ended a conflict with the FLN by signing the Evian Accords.
He was brought to power in the May Crisis, leading to the formation of the Fifth Republic. For ten points,
name this French Prime Minister who led the Free French Forces during WWII.

In this battle, Major Sylvain-Raynal managed to defend Fort Vaux for over a week, but the lightly
defended Fort Douaumont [DOO-oh-MOHN] was captured without a fight. General Nivelle issued the
order “they shall not pass” during this battle, and General Falkenhyn sought to “bleed France white”
in this battle. For ten points, name this extremely bloody 9-month-long battle during World War I at a
French fortress town.

One side’s attack on Saarbrucken early in this war showed the value of their Chassepot [sha-say-poh]
rifles, but was defeated at the Battle of Wissembourg [VISS-em-boorg]. The Army of Chalons was formed
during this war to rescue troops encircled at Metz, and this war was ended by the Treaty of Frankfurt.
The Second Empire was dissolved after a defeat at Sedan in this war. For ten points, name this war that
resulted in the formation of the German Empire and the defeat of Napoleon III.

King Godfred built the Danevirke as a defense against this ruler, and later this ruler concluded the
Treaty of Heiligen with the Hemming. This ruler, who died of pleurisy, was succeeded by his son Louis the
Pious, and three of his grandsons divided his empire in the Treaty of Verdun. This ruler, who was advised
by Alcuin of York, was crowned on Christmas Day by Leo III as Imperator Romanorum. For ten points,
name this King of the Franks who was the first Holy Roman Emperor.

This author wrote about a drunk Pope Julius II who tries to convince Julius into letting him into
heaven in Julius Exclusus, and he advocated for Christians to act with faith in his Handbook of a Christian
Knight. Hans Holbein created drawings for this man’s best known work, which satirizes the workings of
the Catholic Clergy. For ten points, name this Dutch humanist who wrote In Praise of Folly.

A war against the town of Visby led to a conflict between this country and the Hanseatic League.
Christian I was the first member of this country’s Oldenburg dynasty, the oldest continuously reigning
dynasty in Europe. This nation was briefly ascendant over Sweden and Norway in the Kalmar Union and
is currently ruled by Frederik X. For ten points, name this country with capital at Copenhagen.

An attempt to implicate Jews for one of this man’s actions involved an apron located just below the
Goulston Street graffito; that apron belonged to Catherine Eddows. That event proved that this man’s
“Dear Boss” letter wasn’t a hoax. Later, this man mailed a kidney to George Lusk with his “From Hell”
Letter. For ten points, name this officially unidentified serial killer of London’s Whitechapel district.

A photo by Yevgeny Khaldei [khal-DAY] shows a soldier raising a flag atop a building in this city. In
this city, the mural My God, Help Me to Survive This Deadly Love depicts Leonid Brezhnev and Erich
Honecker embracing. Lucius D. Clay led relief during Operation Vittles which was known as this city’s
“Airlift”. For ten points, name this capital of Germany

This leader bribed journalists with the Reptile Fund. His education minister, Adalbert Falk,
administered the May Laws, and he called a conference to modify the Treaty of San Stefano. He also
called another conference of the same name, which incited the Scramble for Africa. This man sent the Ems
dispatch to spark war against France, which resulted in his forming a unified country under the Prussian
monarch Wilhelm I. For ten points, name this Chancellor who unified Germany.

Warning: two answers required. These two countries planned, but never took, a joint voyage to map
a boundary defined as 370 leagues west of Cape Verde. These two countries debated ownership of the
Indonesian Molucca Islands until the 1529 Treaty of Zaragoza, 35 years after they divided New World
territory in the Treaty of Tordesillas [torr-de-SEE-ess]. For ten points, name these two countries on the
Iberian peninsula in southwestern Europe.

This monarch employed Chancellor John Morton and defeated a rebellion at the Battle of Stoke;
that rebellion was led by pretender Lambert Simnel. This monarch, who established the Star Chamber,
defeated a Yorkist king with the help of the Stanley brothers at one battle.This man defeated the forces
of Richard III at the Battle of Bosworth Field, ending the Wars of the Roses. For ten points, name this
first Tudor monarch and father of Henry VIII.

(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) The execution of what victor of the Battle of Stirling Bridge seemed to end the Scottish
War of Independence, prior to the rise of Robert the Bruce?

This event’s fourth principle declared that “superior orders” do not relieve a person from lawful
responsibility. Seven subjects of these events were taken to Spandau. Their location was chosen
symbolically, as it had hosted an annual propaganda rally and was the city where, in 1935, a harsh set of
anti-Semitic laws was signed. Luftwaffe commander Hermann Goring was sentenced to death at, for ten
points, what series of trials in which Nazi leaders were tried for war crimes?

In this modern day country, Boleslaw [boll-eh-slav] the Pious of this country’s Piast Dynasty
granted Jews legal rights with the Statue of Kalisz [kal-eesh]. In this modern day country, the Szaltcha
[SHALL-chah] enacted the Golden Liberty under its Jagiellion [yah-gell-ee-on] dynasty. This modern day
country has been partitioned between Russia, Prussia, and Austria. For ten points, name this eastern
European nation with capital Warsaw.

This ruler faced early trouble from two Eberhards, of Bavaria and Franconia, and his half-brother
Thankmar during his early reign. Liudolf, this man’s son, fought against him before a notable battle, and
John XII crowned this man before being deposed by this ruler. This son of Henry the Fowler was aided by
Conrad the Red to defeat the Magyars at the Battle of Lechfeld. For ten points, name this Saxon German
king, the first Holy Roman Emperor.
(TIEBREAKER BONUS QUESTION) What man became France’s first Socialist president in 1981?

This leader appointed Ian MacGregor as head of the National Coal Board, which closed unprofitable
mines, angering Arthur Scargill. This leader narrowly won a vote of no confidence to depose James
Callaghan, and was succeeded by John Major after a cabinet minister resigned due to her combative style.
This Prime Minister formed a friendship with Ronald Reagan and won the Falklands War. For ten points,
name this Iron Lady, the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

After a war with the Ottomans, this empire annexed Bessarabia and supported the founding of
independent Bulgaria. This empire annexed Khiva and Bukhara during the “Great Game” with the
United Kingdom. In 1825, a succession crisis in this empire led to the Decembrist uprising of soldiers who
supported Grand Duke Constantine, who instead remained in Poland. For ten points, name this empire
that, in the 19th century, was led by three Alexanders from the Romanov family.

tossup.question:
This event was enflamed when a court-martial acquitted Ferdinand Esterhazy. One person
involved in this scandal was imprisoned on Devil’s Island until key evidence against him was
revealed to be forged. Emile Zola wrote the letter J’Accuse supporting that prisoner. For 10
points, name this scandal in which a Jewish French army captain was framed for treason.

bonus.question:
Another 19th century French political scandal concerned Ferdinand de Lesseps’
attempts to build what structure?

tossup.question:
This empire followed the proclamation of the Edict of Gulhane with a fifty year modernization
effort called the Tanzimat Reforms. Some of its armies were composed of irregular “bashibazouks,” while others were composed of janissaries. It was known as the Sick Man of Europe
leading up to World War I. For 10 points, name this empire which centered on Turkey.

bonus.question:
The first president of modern Turkey was what man who implemented a namesake
policy of strict westernization?

tossup.question:
This man first came to prominence by suppressing the 13 Vendémiaire (pr. VON-deem-yair)
rebellion with what Thomas Carlyle called "a whiff of grapeshot." He made his brothers Joseph
and Jerome into the kings of Spain and Westphalia, respectively. For 10 points, name this "First
Counsel" who was defeated by the Duke of Wellington at Waterloo.

bonus.question:
Napoleon was able to remove Austria and the Holy Roman Empire from the Third
Coalition opposing him with what great 1805 victory in what is now the Czech Republic?

tossup.question:
A scandal leading up to this ballot question involved abusive Twitter messages sent to J.K.
Rowling. Alistair Darling appeared in an August 2014 debate on behalf of Better Together,
which led the "no" campaign on this question. For 10 points, identify this September 2014 ballot
question which sought to make Edinburgh the capital of a new sovereign country.

bonus.question:
Which largest Scottish city by population was one of the few areas where the majority
of people voted for independence?

tossup.question:
Troops who carried out this action referred to it as “Blumenkrieg”, a term meaning "war of
flowers," because they were met by cheering crowds. Kurt Schuschnigg (pr. SHOOS-neg) was
forced to resign to clear the way for this action, which began on March 11, 1938. For 10 points,
identify this forced incorporation of Austria into Nazi Germany.

bonus.question:
Austria was forbidden from unifying with Germany by the Treaty of Saint-Germain
(pr. sahn zhair-MON), which was signed at the end of what war?
bonus.answer: World War I, First World War, the Great War

tossup.question:
A bronze age museum is maintained at a "crannog" in County Clare on this island. This island
regained its independence from Viking kingdoms at the 1014 Battle of Clontarf, re-establishing
the High King's seat at the hill of Tara. The Book of Kells can be seen at Trinity College Library
on this island. For 10 points, name this island, also home to the James Joyce Museum in Dublin.

bonus.question: What city in southwest Ireland is the namesake of a humorous poetic form?

tossup.question:
This man’s government organized the Congress of People’s Deputies and signed the
Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty. He introduced economic restructuring known as
"perestroika" (pr. peh-rez-TROY-kuh) and government transparency called "glasnost". For 10
points, name this rival of Boris Yeltsin who was the final leader of the Soviet Union.

bonus.question:
Gorbachev ended the "internal exile" of what dissenting physicist, the inventor of the
Soviet hydrogen bomb and namesake of a human rights prize?

tossup.question:
The U.S. National Archives currently displays David Rubenstein’s copy of this document,
which contains clauses that limited the right of women to use the legal system and limited the
enforcement of debts against children. This document was signed at Runnymede and failed to
quell the Barons Wars. For 10 points, name this limitation of the powers of King John.

bonus.question:
The Second Barons War ended under the rule of what king, whose army was defeated
by William Wallace at Stirling Bridge?

tossup.question:
This empire was targeted by the Unilateral Declaration of Independence, which removed a
colony from this empire to protest its plans for racial integration. This empire's leader gave the
Winds of Change speech as it began to give up control of Ghana, Nigeria, and Rhodesia. For 10
points, name this empire which, along with France, was the largest colonizer of Africa.

bonus.question:
Rhodesia later was renamed as which African country with its capital at the city of
Harare (pr. huh-RAH-ray)?

tossup.question:
This device was originally named for doctor Antoine Louis. The "tricoteuse" (pr. TRICK-awtooz) were women who knitted next to this object. This object was used on up to forty thousand
people at the order of Maximilien Robespierre, who found himself subject to it in 1794. For 10
points, name this item which was used to execute Louis XVI and others during the French
Revolution.

bonus.question:
The guillotine was originally used to equalize execution methods for nobles and
members of what group, the peasant section of France in the Estates-General?

tossup.question:
Popes from this family presided over the Council of Trent and the start of the Protestant
Reformation. This family of Leo X and Pius IV was targeted by the Pazzi (pr. POT-see)
Conspiracy and first rose to power in Tuscany under the banker Cosimo. For 10 points, identify
this political family which ruled Florence through such members as Lorenzo the Magnificent.

bonus.question:
What rival family of Spanish origin included Pope Alexander VI, the poisoner
Lucrezia, and the Machiavelli (pr. MOCK-ee-uh-VEL-ee) patron Cesare (pr. CHAY-zar-ay)?

tossup.question:
The informer "Stakeknife" infiltrated this organization, which began the "Long War" in the
early 1970s. This group claimed responsibility for killing MP Airey Neave as well as the 1984
Brighton hotel bombing which nearly killed Margaret Thatcher. For 10 points, name this militant
Catholic group which advocated transferring Northern Ireland away from the United Kingdom.

bonus.question:
Which 1972 massacre of Irish demonstrators by UK paratroopers shares its name with
a 1905 killing spree in St. Petersburg?

tossup.question:
This queen came to the throne at age six, leading to the creation of a regency council
dominated by Axel Oxenstierna (pr. OCK-sens-TURR-nuh). In 1654, this queen shocked
Europe by abdicating her throne and converting to Catholicism, after which she lived out her life
in Rome. For 10 points, name this daughter of Gustavus Adolphus, an “enlightened monarch” of
Sweden.

bonus.question:
Christina’s energetic studies with what philosopher of Discourse on Method, whom she
summoned to Sweden and often woke before dawn, are thought to have caused his death?

tossup.question:
The Eighth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution copied nearly verbatim this text’s prohibition
on “excessive bail and cruel and unusual punishments.” This document guaranteed freedom of
speech and the right to bear arms, and it also banned Catholics from succeeding to the throne.
For 10 points, name this 1689 law which outlined liberties prior to the Glorious Revolution.

bonus.question:
What editor of The North Briton whose slogan was “No Liberty, No King” caused
repeated scandals in 1760s England by invoking the English Bill of Rights in his campaign
against George III?

tossup.question:
A picket line formed by members of this profession got into a huge brawl with police at the
Battle of Ogreave. Members of this profession who opposed the moderate NACODS joined the
NUM led by Arthur Scargill. Members of this profession were dubbed "the enemy within" by
Margaret Thatcher. For the point, identify this profession which launched a disastrous 1984
British strike which closed down facilities for extracting bitumen.

bonus.question:
Which musical about a boy who wants to be a ballet dancer features a chorus of
disgruntled coal miners complaining about Margaret Thatcher?

tossup.question:
The inefficient Trabant was built in this former country. It used distinctive Ampelmannchen crosswalk
symbols that are now enjoyed as its modern residents experience “Ostalgie.” Its residents were once spied
on by the Markus Wolf-led Stasi, which revealed its records after reunification in 1990. For ten points,
name this former Soviet-zone country with capital Berlin.

bonus.question: The Oder-Neisse Line provided the border between East Germany and what other country?

tossup.question:
This man fought during the Second Baron’s War against Simon de Montfort, who he killed at the
Battle of Evesham. This monarch issued the Edict of Expulsion, which expelled all Jews from England.
He invaded Scotland, winning the Battle of Falkirk against the forces of William Wallace. For ten points,
name this English King given the name “Longshanks” because of his height.

bonus.question:
Edward I’s father Henry III was forced by the barons to agree to the Provisions of Oxford, which
heavily influenced this later document that was signed by John I at Runnymede.

tossup.question:
This position was ended by the Peace of Pressburg, which also created the Confederation of the
Rhine. One holder of this position stood in the snow outside Canossa to do penance, and the successor to
this position was decided by the prince-electors. These men were crowned by popes until 1530, and the
phrase “sacrum” was added to this title by a man who fought the Lombard League. For ten points, name
this position, which was held by Charles V and Frederick Barbarossa.

bonus.question:
A 1356 decree known by this color was issued by Charles IV to set the number of electors to
select the Holy Roman Emperor at seven.

tossup.question:
Alcuin of York’s letters lament these people’s sacking of a priory on the Northumbrian island of
Lindisfarne. The Great Heathen Army legendarily avenged the death of one of their leaders, Ragnar
Lodbrok. Leif Erikson founded their colony of Vinland in the New World. For ten points, name these
Scandinavian sea-faring raiders whose longships dominated medieval Europe for four centuries.

bonus.question: True to his name, this legendary discoverer of Greenland was Leif Erikson’s father.

tossup.question:
The “liquidators” dealt with the aftermath of this event, which was detected after a day in Forsmark,
Sweden. The Red Forest was created by this event, which led to a “zone of alienation” being marked
around the city of Pripyat. It was triggered by a poorly-safeguarded experiment in which control rods
were manually removed, spreading radiation over much of Europe. For ten points, name this 1986 nuclear
meltdown in modern Ukraine.

bonus.question:
The Chernobyl disaster was a major catalyst towards this Soviet premier’s adoption of glasnost,
a policy of openness and government transparency.

tossup.question:
John Mitchel was sent to Bermuda as punishment for his writings about this event. During this event,
people called “soupers” converted to Protestantism in return for aid. The cottier system worsened this
event, in which the affected area received shipments of maize known as “Peel’s brimstone” and remained
a net food exporter to Britain. For ten points, over a million people starved in what event in which the
staple crop of an island west of Britain was ruined by blight?

bonus.question:
In response to the Irish Potato Famine, Prime Minister Robert Peel repealed what set of tariffs
on imported grain in 1846?

tossup.question:
This person’s childhood friend, the Princess de Lamballe, was murdered in the September Massacres.
The Carnation Plot attempted to save this monarch, a suspected lover of Axel Fersin. This monarch was
wrongly blamed in the Diamond Necklace affair and was derisively called “the Austrian”. For ten points,
name this Queen of France, who may have said “let them eat cake” and was guillotined after her husband
Louis XVI.

bonus.question:
Axel Fersin helped plan the escape of Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI from France, but they
were recognized at this small town near the border between Montmedy and Saint-Menehould.

tossup.question:
This ruler ignited a rebellion after appointing Yuri Dolgoruki to round up fugitive peasants in lands
led by Kondraty Bulavin. This ruler signed the Treaty of Constantinople with Mustafa II, which led to
this ruler creating his country’s first navy base on the Sea of Azov. He instituted a beard tax for the
boyars and traveled incognito to observe a Dutch shipyard as part of his Grand Embassy. For ten points,
name this “great” Czar whose modernization included the founding of Saint Petersburg.

bonus.question: Peter I was a part of this Russian Dynasty which ruled Russia until the fall of Nicholas II.

tossup.question:
This year saw the National Liberal party push Frederick VII to create a new constitution, which made
him share power with the Rigsdag. This year saw William O’Brien lead the Young Irelander Rebellion,
and the March Revolution in this year in Germany led to the Frankfurt Assembly offering the German
crown to Wilhelm IV. Klemens von Metternich resigned as Chancellor of Austria in this year, which
saw the establishment of the French Second Republic. For ten points, name this year that saw multiple
revolutions against various European Governments.

bonus.question: Wilhelm IV was from this royal line that would rule Imperial Germany until the end of WW1.

tossup.question:
This party lost an election to Stanley Baldwin due to the Zinoviev Letter. This party’s 1983 election
manifesto was called by one man as the “longest suicide note in history”. James Callaghan of this
party suffered the Winter of Discontent which saw the rise of the opposition party’s leader Margaret
Thatcher. For ten points, name this British political party formerly led by Ed Milliband which opposes
the Conservatives and Liberals.

bonus.question:
Ed Milliband was replaced by this self-described democratic socialist as leader of the Labour
Party after an abysmal showing in the UK 2015 elections. This MP from Islington North was originally
considered a fringe candidate.

tossup.question:
This man built a fort on Aethelney Hill while hiding out in the Somerset marshes. Bishop Asser relates
how this man was once scolded by an old woman for letting a bunch of cakes burn, and he baptized one
rival as his godson; he defeated that rival at the battle of Eddington. This victor of the Battle of Ashdown
fortified his country with a system of burhs. For ten points, name this ruler, the enemy of Guthrum of
Mercia and king of Wessex, who was known as “the Great.”

bonus.question:
Alfred succeeded the first King of this name as leader of Wessex. The second English leader of
this name earned the epithet “the Unready” for the poor counsel of his advisors.

tossup.question:
The Flight of the Wild Geese refers to one group of these people who left Ireland. Machiavelli praised
one type of them, although he considers them as useless as auxiliaries. Leaders of these in Italy were called
condottieri [con-doh-tee-AIR-ee], and the battle of Marignano saw the ascendancy of the Landsknecht
over the most famous of these types of soldiers, who were recruited from their cantons and carried pikes.
Swiss pikemen were, for ten points, what hired soldiers?

bonus.question:
Swiss mercenaries were most commonly hired by what nation, whose Francis I employed them
at the battles of Marignano and Pavia?

tossup.question:
Alexander Suvorov invaded this country through the St. Gotthard Pass during the French
Revolutionary wars. The Toggenburg War was fought by the Old Confederacy of this country, which
was formed from Uri, Schwyz, and Unterwalden. The Kappel wars were fought in this country, where
Napoléon established the Helvetic Republic. Zürich is one of eight Old Cantons in, for ten points, what
Alpine country that has its capital at Bern?

bonus.question:
This author of Institutes of the Christian Religion and supporter of predestination fled to
Switzerland and eventually led the church of Geneva.

tossup.question:
This king wrote the Defence of the Seven Sacraments attacking Martin Luther, for which he was
rewarded with the title Defender of the Faith from Clement VII. This man, who passed the first Act
of Supremacy and dissolved the monasteries, ordered his chief ministers Cardinal Wolsey and Thomas
Cromwell to arrange an annulment and marriage to Anne Boleyn. For ten points, name this King who
founded the Church of England so that he could divorce the first of his six wives.

bonus.question:
Henry’s first, fifth, and sixth wives had this name. The first was a relative of Ferdinand and
Isabella of Spain, the fifth was executed after sixteen months for adultery, and the last survived by
outliving Henry.

tossup.question:
This ruler was forced to retreat through the Derbend Pass after his invasion of Sassanid Persia. This
man’s uncle Ruga united his people, then was succeeded by this man and his brother, Bleda. Aetius was
forced to ally with Theodoric in order to defeat this ruler, who may have begun an invasion after Honoria
sent him a ring. According to legend, this ruler died of a nosebleed. For ten points, name this “Scourge of
God” who attempted to sack Rome as the leader of the Huns.

bonus.question: Upon invading Italy, Attila was confronted by Leo I, a holder of this religious position, outside Rome.

tossup.question:
During this war, murderous mitrailleuse [mih-tray-uhs] and Chassepot [shass-poh] fire stalled one
side’s attacks at the Battle of Gravelotte. After this war, Baden, Wurtemburg, and Bavaria joined a
country that also gained Alsace-Lorraine through the Treaty of Frankfurt. This war ended shortly after
the losing leader was captured at the Battle of Sedan. For ten points, name this war in which Napoleon
III was soundly defeated by a state led by Otto von Bismarck.

bonus.question:
Prussia was the first country to adopt the use of this material for making artillery, which helped
it win the Franco-Prussian War. Krupp guns are made of this material.

tossup.question:
The Third Section was one of these organizations before it was succeeded by the Okhrana. Before
he held his highest post, Yuri Andropov was the head of one of these organizations. One of these
organizations, the oprichniki, targeted the boyars and executed the Massacre of Novgorod. A feared one of
these during the Cold War was known as the Committee for State Security, or the KGB. For ten points,
name these organizations that suppressed dissent in Russia.

bonus.question:
During Yuri Andropov’s tenure as head of the KGB, he advocated for the Soviet Union’s 1979
invasion of this country, often described as the USSR’s “Vietnam.”

q3.prompt: During or after the Congress of Vienna, what...

questions.question: French emperor was exiled to Saint Helena?
Austrian statesmen hosted the forum?
General who was victorious at Waterloo joined Castlereagh in representing the UK?
Czar of Russia led the Russian delegation?
Country retained control of the Cape Colony and Tobago?
Minister for Louis XVIII headed the French delegation?
Country regained control of Tyrol and Ragusa?
Country was represented by Cael Lowenhielm, an illegitimate son of its king Charles XIII?

q3.prompt: In the Middle Ages, who or what was the...

questions.question: Empire which, by the 1070s, was reduced to the area around Constantinople?
questions.answer: Byzantine, Byzantine Empire, Eastern Roman Empire, Eastern Roman

questions.question:
Country first organized by the Piast Dynasty, which was later invaded by its neighbor
Germany to start World War II?
Muslim empire based in Turkey which conquered much of the region from 1308 to 1571?
Modern-day country where the Grand Duchy of Muscovy formed around the city of Moscow?
Group which briefly overran Eastern Europe after defeating the Hungarians at Mohi in 1241?

City where Vladimir the Great converted a namesake state to Christianity before it became the
Ukrainian capital?

Prince of Wallachia (pr. wah-LAY-kee-uh) whose practice of putting opposing soldiers on
stakes inspired vampire legends?
questions.answer: Vlad the Impaler, Vlad Dracula, Dracula, Vlad III, Vlad Tepes

questions.question:
Battle, which shares its name with a Balkan country that declared independence in 2008 from
Serbia?

q3.prompt: Medieval emperor Charlemagne...

questions.question:
Was crowned on Christmas 800 by Leo III, a holder of what top office of the Catholic
Church?
Instigated the "Carolingian" example of what sort of period in which arts and learning revive?

Launched a crusade against what Germanic people, who earlier joined with the Angles to
conquer England?
In 797, took control of what currently second largest city in Spain?
Was the son of what small-statured king?
questions.answer: Pepin the Short, Pepin III, Pepin le Bref, Pippin der Kurze

questions.question: Was gifted what kind of large animal, known as Abul-Abbas, by the Abbasid caliph?
Was the leader of which Germanic tribe who were earlier led by the Merovingians?
Was the grandson of what Mayor of the Palace who won the Battle of Tours?
questions.answer: Charles Martel, Carolus Martellus, Karl Martell

questions.question: Increasingly chaotic German “empire” whose member states took opposing sides?
Major world religion whose Protestant Reformation was one of the war’s ultimate causes?
Treaty which formally ended the conflict?

Activity which peaked during the war, and used the Malleus Mallificarum to determine whom to
burn?
Country whose pragmatic policy was made by Cardinal Richelieu (pr. ree-shell-OO)?
Event in which two diplomats were thrown out a window that sparked the fighting?
King of Sweden who was killed at the Battle of Lutzen?
Watershed historical year in which it ended?

q3.prompt: In the 1990s, who or what was the...

questions.question: City where the Jubilee underground line on the tube was extended?
Holiday shortly before Easter for which a Northern Ireland peace accord was named?
Labour Party Prime Minister who began his ten-year term in 1997?
City whose “United” soccer team was managed by Sir Alex Ferguson?
City where a Scottish parliament was established?
Longtime Chancellor of the Exchequer who ultimately succeeded to the premiership in 2007?
Five-member "girl group" whose song "Wannabe" led the British pop culture revival?
1992 treaty creating the European Union which Britain joined?

q3.prompt: In the era of the Crusades, who or what was the...

questions.question: Religion whose Crusaders sought to capture Jerusalem from Muslim Turks?

Religious group which was the target of pogroms in the Rhineland at the hands of the People's
Crusade?
King of England who left his brother John in charge while he led the Third Crusade?

Kurdish founder of the Ayyubid (pr. eye-OO-bid) Dynasty who was the opponent of the
Third Crusade?
Sea across which Crusaders sailed to the Holy Land?

Type of defensive building, such as Krak des Chevaliers (pr. KRAG doo shoo-vahl-YAY),
often constructed by Crusaders?
Pope who called for the First Crusade?
Crusade which descended into looting and sacked Constantinople?

q3.prompt: The emancipation of the world's largest serf population...

questions.question: Occurred in what empire, which was ultimately ended by the deposition of Tsar Nicholas II?
Began in what year, also the year Abraham Lincoln's Presidency and the Civil War started?
Was instigated by what tsar, who was assassinated twenty years later?

Ended the landlord veto over serfs engaging in what practice, the subject of the American
court case Loving v. Virginia?
Was part of the fallout from Russia's defeat by Britain, France, and Turkey in what war?

Led radicals to support what political position that characterized the Nechaevists, Land and
Liberty, and The People's Will?
Set up what system of elected provincial councils?
Required that former serfs do what for forty-nine years?
answer: submit redemption payments to former owners

q3.prompt: In England during the time of Queen Victoria, who or what was the...

questions.question:
Author of A Christmas Carol and Great Expectations who complained about social
conditions?

Long-term economic phenomenon in which mechanized factories became the dominant sector
of the economy?
Serial killer who targeted prostitutes in London in 1888?
Major British possession in Asia, which Victoria was declared Empress of?
City that was the world’s most populous throughout Victoria’s reign?
Conservative Party leader whom Victoria favored over his rival Gladstone?

Playwright and author of The Picture of Dorian Grey who was sentenced to jail for his
sexuality?
Famous Crimean War era poem written by Tennyson about a disastrous cavalry mission?
questions.answer: The Charge of the Light Brigade

q3.prompt: The Spanish Armada was...

questions.question: Sent off in what historic year?
Attempting to return England to what religion?
Sent against what Queen of England?
Funded in part by Spanish conquests over what Native Americans of the Andes Mountains?
Initially combatted by what commander of the Golden Hind?

Shattered near the Munster and Connacht (pr. cuh-NOKT) areas of what island when it was
blown off course on its return?
Organized by what Spanish king?
Unsuccessfully commanded by what Spanish military officer?
answer: Don Alonso Perez de Guzman y de Zuniga-Sotomayor

q3.prompt: In World War I, who or what was...

questions.question:
The country which exited the war following the Bolshevik Revolution and organized the
USSR five years later?
The palace outside Paris where the main peace treaty was signed?
The archduke whose assassination sparked the conflict?
The assassin responsible for that archduke's death?
The country whose violated neutrality was a proximate cause of Britain’s entering the war?
The high commander of American forces in the war?
The German war plan which involved quickly defeating France before fighting Russia?
The August 1914 battle where Hindenburg and Ludendorff destroyed a Russian army?

q3.prompt: Benito Mussolini...

questions.question: Was the dictator of what country?
Promoted what ideology named for a Roman bundle of sticks?
Took on what title meaning "leader?"

Authorized the invasion of what African country in 1935, displacing Haile Selassie (hai-LEH
se-lah-SEE)?
Entered what agreement in May 1939, formally creating the Axis?
Led the invasion of what country in 1939, causing the overthrow of King Zog?
Was killed trying to flee to which country that borders Italy?
Eventually was hung upside down outside a gas station in which largest Northern Itailan city?

q3.prompt: England's South Sea Bubble scandal of 1720...

questions.question:
Arose over a company which transported what kind of people in the "Middle Passage" after
forcible abduction from Africa?
Led to the creation of what office, later held by Margaret Thatcher and David Cameron?
answer: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom

questions.question: Occurred during the reign of what first Hanoverian king?

Led to the ascension of what party, which opposed the Tories in the eighteenth-century British
party system?

Temporarily soured the English investor class on what form of business entity which preceded
corporations and was prominent during the Age of Exploration?
Arose from an attempt to exploit the Treaty of Utrecht, which ended what war in 1713?
Was resolved by what politician who dominated the British government until 1742?
Caused the creation of what institution, which manages UK monetary policy?

q3.prompt: In Italy after World War II, who or what was the...

questions.question: Ideology advocated by the Red Brigades terrorist group and Italy's neighbor Yugoslavia?
Organized crime phenomenon which was curtailed in the "Maxi trial?"
Organization formed by the Maastricht Treaty which Italy was an architect of?
Western military alliance which orchestrated Operation Gladio in Italy?

Media mogul who became Italy's right-wing prime minister three times and was frequently
charged with corruption?
Milan-based designer who founded what is now Italy's largest men's fashion house in 1975?
Umbrella auto manufacturer which now owns Ferrari, Maserati, and Chrysler?
Name commonly given to the period of political violence from 1969 to the mid-1980s?

q3.category: THE COURT OF THE FRENCH KING
q3.prompt: What important person in the reigns of the final four kings of pre-Revolutionary France was...

questions.question: A radical free speech advocate and the author of Candide?

A finance minister whose cheapness caused his name to be applied to an all-black outline
portrait?
The king from 1610 to 1643 who ended the regency of Marie de Medici?
The thinker who explained separation of powers in The Spirit of the Laws?
The Catholic "Red Eminence" who dominated the court in the 1620s and 30s?
The influential mistress of Louis XV with a flamboyant hairstyle?

The formulator of the law of conservation of mass and the metric system who was executed by
the Revolution despite being the "Father of Modern Chemistry?"

The composer of religious music for Louis XIV who died after shattering his foot with a
baton?

q3.prompt: Which Eastern European country...

questions.question: Unified the cities of Buda and Pest in 1873?
Was in a union with Montenegro until 2006?
Broke away from the Czech Republic in 1993?
Had 7 border guards killed in a Soviet assault near Vilnius?
Is home to electrician, politician, and Nobel Peace Prize winner Lech Walesa [vah-WE-sa]?
Is the modern site of the former capital of the Kievan Rus?
Saw its leader, Nicolae Ceausescu [CHO-ses-koo], executed for war crimes in a 1989 revolution?
Was considered the “last dictatorship in Europe” under Alexander Lukashenko?

q3.prompt: What is...

questions.question: The once-divided German capital city?

The Christian holiday celebrated with street markets called Weihnachtsmarkt [VYE-nakts-markt]
and advent calendars?
The sibling storytellers of fairy tales like Hansel and Gretel?
The highway system whose efficiency and lack of speed limits inspired President Eisenhower?
The Bavarian capital city whose beer halls sponsor the annual Oktoberfest?
The NBA MVP who has played 17 seasons for the Dallas Mavericks?
The founder of the Bayreuth [bye-ROYT] opera house, where his Ring Cycle is annually performed?
The German art and architecture school founded by Walter Gropius?

q3.prompt: Which British Prime Minister from the 20th and 21st centuries...

questions.question: Is the current PM (2025)?
served during most of World War II, offering nothing but “blood, toil, tears, and sweat?”
was known as the Iron Lady?
attended the 1919 Paris Peace Conference and helped organize the Treaty of Versailles?
signed the Munich Agreement with Hitler, proclaiming “peace in our time”?
replaced his predecessor as the new Labour PM at the 1945 Potsdam Conference?
was criticized for sending troops to Iraq in 2003?
was comparably less criticized for sending troops to Iraq in 1991?

q3.prompt: In the history of the Byzantine Empire, who or what was...

questions.question: Its capital city, originally known as Byzantium and now known as Istanbul?
The Italian city whose empire it continued in the east?
The empire that arose after conquering the Byzantine Empire, which lasted until World War 1?
The official monotheistic religion of the empire, after a decree by Theodosius?
The religious images banned by Leo III in the 8th century?

Germanic tribe conquered by Belisarius in north Africa, whose name now refers to general destruction
of property?
The wife of Justinian who convinced him not to flee from the Nika Riots?
The Ottoman sultan who conquered Constantinople in 1453, ending the Byzantine Empire?

q3.prompt: In the history of the Inquisition, who or what is...

questions.question: The Iberian country for which it is often named, home to cities such as Castille?

The religion of the Moors, who were simultaneously being expelled from the Iberian Peninsula in the
Reconquista?

The other commonly persecuted religion during the Inquisition, who were expelled by the Alhambra
Decree?
The other Iberian country to which the Inquisition spread?
The term for public penance by the condemned, usually in the form of a public burning?

The torture device in which a victim’s wrists and ankles are strapped to a frame and gradually pulled
apart?
The base city for Tomas de Torquemada’s first tribunal?
The Dostoyevsky novel in which, in a parable, Christ is confronted by Grand Inquisitor Torquemada?

q3.prompt: In European naval history, what is...

questions.question: The country whose Baltic Sea ports include Kaliningrad and St. Petersburg?
The term for German submarines that harassed Allied shipping during World Wars 1 and 2?
The fleet of over 100 ships whose invasion of England was thwarted by Francis Drake?
The country that has naval yards at Szczecin [st-etch-in] and Gdansk?
The battle at which Lord Nelson died?

The French city where British fishing boats and little ships ferried evacuated Allied soldiers from the
Nazis?

The October 1571 galley battle in which the Holy League devastated an Ottoman fleet in the Ionian
Sea?
The Nazi operation that would have invaded Britain if naval superiority had been achieved?

q3.prompt: In World War II, which country...

questions.question: Was allied with Germany until the Allies invaded it and captured Rome?
Was the first to be invaded by Germany, on September 1, 1939?
Created the Maginot Line to defend against Germany, but quickly surrendered anyway?
Was invaded by Nazi Germany during Operation Barbarossa and later captured Berlin?
Allied with Germany after it lost the Winter War?
Was the site of a German invasion at Trondheim, and was led by Vidkun Quisling?
Maintained a policy of neutrality while buying stolen German gold?
Was the Eastern European site of the Ploiesti [ploy-esh-tee] oilfields, vital to the Nazi war effort?

q3.prompt: Name the...

questions.question: Longest reigning monarch of the United Kingdom.
Iberian country ruled by just two queens named Maria, who also ruled over Brazil.

Pious queen of Castile who authorized the first Spanish colonization efforts and was married to
Ferdinand of Aragon.
Beheaded queen who legendarily said “Let them eat cake!”
Stuart queen who tried to overthrow Elizabeth I and was subsequently executed.
Low country in Northern Europe ruled by Queen Beatrix in the 20th century.

Position held by two of Henry VIII’s queens, who governed in place of a monarch who cannot rule
due to absence, sickness, or youth.

Duchess of Aquitaine who became Queen of both England and France and helped form the Angevin
Empire.

parts:
(30 pts) This person was the subject of a "nullification trial" convened by Calixtus III. This
person led troops that captured John Talbot at the Battle of Patay. After getting an
audience with (20 pts)

Charles VII, this person correctly identified the disguised king. This hero
of the Siege of (10 pts)

Orleans claimed to have visions of St. Michael and St. Margaret. For 10
points, name this woman who was burned at the stake after fighting for the French in the
Hundred Year's War.

(30 pts) This country's central bank adopted a policy of “forward guidance” for future interest
rates after the 2008 financial crisis. It froze Icelandic bank assets in 2008 after Iceland
refused to guarantee its banks' debts to creditors in this country. The Chancellor of the (20 pts)

Exchequer proposed large spending cuts in 2010 as part of the austerity program of its
former prime minister, (10 pts)

David Cameron. For 10 points, name this country whose
government nationalized the Royal Bank of Scotland.

(30 pts) Roger Ascham described the use of this weapon in the manual Toxophilus, and it survived in the British army until World War II, when Jack Churchill killed a Nazi soldier with one of them. These weapons were sometimes named for the (20 pts)
Welsh people who invented them and perfected their use, and they were used to great effect by the English at (10 pts)
Agincourt (pr. AA-jin-core). For 10 points, name this six-foot-tall archery weapon which replaced the crossbow.
(30 pts) This man won a Nobel Prize in Literature for his History of the English-Speaking Peoples. This man was First Lord of the Admiralty during the (20 pts)
Gallipoli disaster, though his "wilderness years" eventually ended and allowed him to make the "we shall (10 pts)
fight them on the beaches" speech. He was defeated in his first re-election bid by Clement Attlee. For 10 points, name this leader of the national unity government of the U.K. during World War II.
(30 pts) Members of this organization were represented in the Reichstag by the Centre Party. This organization was targeted by Adalbert von Falk's May Laws, part of the (20 pts)
Kulturkampf (pr. KOOL-tur-kompf) against it launched by Otto von Bismarck. A leader of this organization who was accused of turning a blind eye to the Holocaust was (10 pts)
Pius XII. For 10 points, name this organization which is the predominant Christian denomination in southern Germany.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) This city was the site of a Church council held five years before the Council of Constance which elected Alexander V as Pope in an attempt to end the Western Schism. This city was the loser of the Battle of (20 pts)
Meloria, and it was where a man allegedly dropped (10 pts)

cannonballs out of a window in order to measure acceleration. For 10 points, name this home to a gravitational experiment by Galileo, who made use of an architectural blunder that created its "leaning tower."

(30 pts) A person by this name was the fanatically Catholic Duke of Guise (pr. GHEEZ) while
another man of this name was the final king of the Valois (pr. val-WAH) Dynasty. Another
man of this name was originally the king of (20 pts)

Navarre and said "Paris is worth a mass" to
explain his conversion to Catholicism. (10 pts)

For 10 points, give this name of three men who fought
the last French War of Religion, including the first Bourbon king of France.

(30 pts) This man led a legion in support of the Colorado Party during the Uruguayan Civil War.
He later took command of the Hunters of the Alps to fight against Austria, which challenged
his project that included the Siege of (20 pts)

Gaeta undertaken by the Expedition of the
Thousand. This man allied with Count (10 pts)

Cavour to achieve the Risorgimento (pr. reeSORGE-ee-MEN-toe). For 10 points, name this general who led the Redshirts on a successful
campaign to unify Italy.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) This man revised the pamphlet The Falsifiers of History to present his side of 1930s events,
and he gave the "Dizzy From Success" speech to explain why he was modifying goals of the (20 pts)

First Five-Year Plan. This leader orchestrated the "show trials" of army generals and
others, decimating his military before the (10 pts)

Nazi invasion of his country in Operation
Barbarossa. For 10 points, name this fan of gulags who was the dictator of the Soviet Union from
1924 to 1953.

(30 pts) Theodor Adorno said that after the existence of this place, writing poetry is barbaric.
This place was built near a massive, forty-four track (20 pts)

railway junction and was
commanded by Rudolph Hoss. At the main gate of this place, the words "Arbeit Macht
Frei" (pr. ARR-bite mokt FRY), meaning (10 pts)

"work makes free," were spelled out in iron. It
was adjacent to the Birkenau extermination center. For 10 points, name this most active Nazi
death camp, found in Poland.

(30 pts) In an 1890 treaty, this empire abandoned its interest in Zanzibar in exchange for an
oddly shaped territory that granted it access to the Zambezi River, known as the Caprivi
Strip. This empire perpetrated the Herero genocide in what is now (20 pts)

Namibia. It had to
give up what are now Tanzania and Cameroon following its defeat in (10 pts)

World War I. For
10 points, name this European-based empire, which was originally constructed by Otto von
Bismarck.

(30 pts) A succession war named for this area began on the death of Maximilian Joseph in 1777
and was also known as the "potato war." Motifs from Wagner (pr. VOG-ner) operas are
used to decorate the (20 pts)

Neuschwanstein (pr. noy-SHVON-shtine) Castle in this region,
which was built by its (10 pts)

"Mad" king Ludwig II. For 10 points, name this southeastern German
state and historic kingdom, where many German Catholics and the city of Munich can be found.

(30 pts) This man coined the name "scissors crisis" during the period of the New Economic
Policy. He also created the term "degenerated workers state" to summarize his views on
what the (20 pts)

Soviet Union became following his deposition as head of the Red Army. He
was ultimately killed in (10 pts)

Mexico by Ramon Mercador. For 10 points, name this member of
the Left Opposition who was outmaneuvered by Joseph Stalin for leadership of the USSR.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) This king was the beneficiary of the original Act of Supremacy. He raised funds for the
middle part of his reign by dissolving nearly all monasteries in his kingdom, with the
assistance of his first administrator Thomas (20 pts)

Wolsey. This king was the father of
Edward VI, (10 pts)

Mary I, and Elizabeth I. For 10 points, name this king whose attempt to divorce
Catherine of Aragon triggered the English Reformation and his five subsequent marriages.

(30 pts) During this larger operation, soldiers were executed at Chenogne (pr. chay-NON) in
revenge for the earlier Malmedy (pr. mahl-may-DEE) Massacre. Anthony McAuliffe issued
the singular reply (20 pts)

"Nuts!" to a surrender demand during this operation, which was
named for the (10 pts)

shape created in a map of troop lines in the Ardennes forest. For 10 points,
name this late 1944 World War II initiative, the final major German offensive of the war.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) A major terrorist group in this country absorbed the Socialist Patients' Collective, a group
which believes that people with illnesses were the oppressed class in capitalist societies, and
launched a 1977 campaign known as its "autumn." This home of the (20 pts)

Red Army Faction
was also where members of (10 pts)

Black September targeted athletes in 1972. For 10 points, name
this country where terrorist incidents included the attack on Israelis at the Munich Olympics.

(30 pts) This emperor was the ultimate victor of the Battle of Muhlberg, which suppressed the
Schmalkaldic (pr. shmal-CALL-dik) League that opposed him. This man's 1525 victory at (20 pts)
Pavia included the capture of Francis I of France. This father of Philip II summoned (10 pts)

Martin Luther to the Diet of Worms (pr. VURMZ). For 10 points, name this Hapsburg who
briefly united the thrones of Spain and the Holy Roman Empire.

(30 pts) This body was originally under the influence of John Pym and the radical "Five
Members," and it was convened to raise money following the Bishops' Wars. This body
steadily lost members, ending up named sardonically for Nicholas (20 pts)

Barebones, after its
moderate delegates were removed in Pride's Purge to create the (10 pts)

Rump Parliament. For 10
points, name this Parliament which oversaw the English Civil War and is named because it sat
from 1640 to 1660.

(30 pts) Guns fired from this building ended the Battle of the Faubourg St. Antoine (pr. foo-BOO
sont AHN-twan) during the Fronde. This building is where the Marquis de (20 pts)

Sade enraged
crowds by claiming a plot to massacre its inhabitants. Only seven politically unimportant (10 pts)

prisoners were found inside when it was stormed on July 14, 1789. For 10 points, name this
Paris prison which was destroyed to start the French Revolution.

(30 pts) This country's colony fought Susquehannock Indians in the Peach War and granted
religious freedom in the Flushing Remonstrance. Prior to England, this country sponsored
the original American voyages of Henry (20 pts)
Hudson. This country conquered the shortlived New Sweden colony in present-day Delaware, under the leadership of Peter (10 pts)
Stuyvesant. For 10 points, name this country which originally colonized what is now New York.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) This battle turned on the use of a perpendicular two-column approach, and the few losing
ships that escaped were led by Federico Gravina. Prior to this battle, a (20 pts)

semaphore
message reading "England expects that every man will do his duty" was transmitted from
the (10 pts)

Victory. For 10 points, name this 1805 naval battle at which Pierre-Charles Villeneuve
was defeated by Horatio Nelson, who died during the fighting and is commemorated at a
namesake London square.

(30 pts) One leader of this conflict, Jose Sanjurjo, died in a plane crash after leaving Estoril.
The term “Fifth Column” was coined during this war. The Abraham Lincoln Brigade was
one of the International Brigades to join this conflict, and (20 pts)

Nazi Germany supported
one side in this conflict with the Condor Legion. After seizing (10 pts)

Cartagena, Republican forces
surrendered to the Nationalists. For ten points, name this conflict in an Iberian country that brought
Francisco Franco to power.

(30 pts) This man destroyed the Vandals after his generals won the battles of Tricamerum and
Ad Decimum. The Secret History by Procopius detailed the rule of this emperor and his
marriage to a (20 pts)

courtesan who convinced him to stay after a riot by the Blues and
Greens. This survivor of the Nika Riots formed the (10 pts)

Corpus Juris Civilis, later known as his
namesake “Code.” For ten points, name this Byzantine emperor who built the Hagia Sophia.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) The Marquis of Pombal established the Douro Wine Company in this country. A
succession crisis in this country was sparked after the death of (20 pts)

Sebastian I at the
Battle of the Three Kings. It gained its independence from its eastern neighbor in the
Restoration War. The House of (10 pts)

Braganza ruled, for ten points, what Iberian country
that colonized Brazil?

(30 pts) This city’s empire defeated Ercole d’Este to conquer Commachio and defeated a rival in
the War of Chioggia. It was targeted by the League of (20 pts)

Cambrai, founded by its nemesis
Julius II. Its Arsenale was said to be able to produce one (10 pts)

warship a day. A fleet from this
city was led by Enrico Dandolo in the Fourth Crusade and sacked Constantinople. For ten points, name
this “Most Serene Republic” which was ruled by doges.

(30 pts) One man involved in this event used the name John Johnson, and people involved in
this event took shelter at the Holbeche House. Francis (20 pts)

Tresham and Thomas Wintour
were executed for their role in this event, and the plan for this event was uncovered in an
anonymous letter sent to Lord (10 pts)

Monteagle. Robert Catesby served as the leader behind this
event, which saw Guy Fawkes discovered guarding ammunition. For ten points, name this plot to blow up
the British Parliament and assassinate James I.

(30 pts) According to William of Poitiers, Pope Alexander II gave a papal banner to one leader
prior to this battle. That leader led an attacking force landed in Pevensey, even though they
intended to land in the (20 pts)

Isle of Wight. The other side in this battle had a defensive
position on Senlac Hill, where one losing leader was shot in the (10 pts)

eye. This battle is depicted
on the Bayeux Tapestry, which shows the death of Harold Godwinson. For ten points, name this 1066
victory for William the Conqueror, who afterward would establish Norman rule of England.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) In response to this event, Mossad launched Operation Wrath of God and
Operation Spring of Youth. This event’s perpetrators demanded the release of
Andreas Baader and (20 pts)
Ulrike Meinhoff, the founders of the Red Army Faction, (10 pts)

Haganah. For ten points, name this event that saw members of Black September kill 11 Israeli
coaches and athletes at the 1972 Summer Olympics in a certain German city.

(30 pts) Foreigners such as the Scotsman Thomas Gordon were often invited to lead this
organization. One portion of this organization nearly sparked (20 pts)

war with Great Britain
while being deployed to relieve another part of this organization, which had been bottled up
in Port Arthur. That force would proceed to have its T crossed by (10 pts)

Heihachiro Togo and
be destroyed at the Battle of Tsushima Straits. The Baltic and Pacific fleets were part of, for ten points,
what military organization, which experienced a revolt on the battleship Potemkin?

(30 pts) Thomas Percy and Charles Neville attempted to overthrow this monarch in the Rising
of the North. This monarch supported the Dutch in one conflict by signing the Treaty of
Nonsuch, and Francis Walsingham uncovered a plot to assassinate this monarch by Anthony (20 pts)

Babington, which led to the execution of this monarch’s cousin, Mary Stuart. This
monarch spoke of having a “heart and stomach of a (10 pts)

king” in a speech to troops at Tilbury.
The Spanish Armada targeted, for ten points, what “Virgin Queen” of England?

(30 pts) This group sometimes dressed in women’s clothing as their founder’s “wives,” and
carried out their acts using a tool they called “Great Enoch.” This group first appeared in
Nottingham and were threatened with (20 pts)

capital punishment with the Frame Breaking
Act. E. J. Hobsbawm referred to their (10 pts)

sabotage as “collective bargaining by riot.” For ten
points, what British textile workers in the early 19th century smashed machines that were replacing their
labor and now give their name to those who oppose technological progress?

(30 pts) The Duc de Longueville represented the French during the negotiations of this treaty.
Despite this treaty, Spain and France did not cease hostilities until the Treaty of the (20 pts)

Pyrenees, and Sweden annexed Bremen after the signature of this treaty. It affirmed the
independence of Switzerland and the Netherlands, and it extended the (10 pts)

Peace of Augsburg
by allowing Calvinism to be a German state’s official religion. For ten points, name this peace treaty that
ended the Thirty Years War.

(30 pts) This man founded the newspaper The Spark for his political party. He argued that
countries would fight until the rise of socialist governments in the work (20 pts)

Imperialism,
the Highest Stage of Capitalism. He advocated for “state capitalism” in his New Economic
Policy as a replacement for “war communism.” In his pamphlet (10 pts)

“What is to be Done?”
this man pushed for the formation of a Vanguard Party to lead the government. For ten points, name this
Soviet leader who led the Bolsheviks during the October Russian Revolution.

(30 pts) This lawyer from Arras was blamed for not stopping the September Massacres. This
leader of the Montagnards attempted to weaken the movement of de-Christianization by
creating the Cult of the (20 pts)

Supreme Being. He shared power with Lazare Carnot and
Louis Saint-Just in his highest position, and he executed the (10 pts)

Girondins and Georges Danton
before being overthrown in the Thermidorian Reaction. For ten points, name this Jacobin who ruled
during the “Reign of Terror.”

(30 pts) After being defeated in World War I, this country lost much of its land in the Treaty of
Trianon, but some of that land was later restored by Austria in the First Vienna Award.
The Nazi-backed (20 pts)

Arrow Cross Party ended this country’s “regency” after it overthrew
Miklos (10 pts)

Horthy. In the aftermath of World War II, this country was occupied by the Soviet Union,
which later put down this country’s 1956 Revolution. For ten points, name this European country with
capital Budapest.

(30 pts) One battle at this site saw Bruno von Mudra and Karl von Eimen lead assaults on
the French Fourth army under Henri Gouraud. Another battle here was preceded by the
replacement of Charles (20 pts)

Lanzerac with Louis d’Esprey for “lacking offensive spirit.”
After that battle, Helmuth (10 pts)

Von Moltke proclaimed “Majesty, we have lost the war” and
abandoned the Schlieffen plan. Taxicabs brought soldiers to, for ten points, what site of an early Allied
victory in WW1 that saved Paris?

(30 pts) The fall of this government led to the deportation of many to New Caledonia. Gustave
Courbet was a member of this government, which ordered the fall of the (20 pts)

Vendome
Column. Many of this government’s officials were executed on the Wall of the Federalists in
Pere Lachaise Cemetery. (10 pts)

Marshall MacMahon led an army that repressed this government during
the “Bloody Week”. For ten points, name this radical socialist government that formed in the French
capital in 1871.

(30 pts) Hochwald was one of this entity’s over one hundred ouvrages. This entity also included
designated flood zones, but it was not extended to the (20 pts)

English Channel. It was named
after the minister of War who proposed it, and it failed to protect the (10 pts)

Ardennes forest.
For ten points, name this defensive line built by the French to protect against German invasion, which
failed when the Nazis avoided it by invading through Belgium instead.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) This event’s capture of Gwailor by forces under Tatya Tose preceded that man’s
betrayal at the hands of Man (20 pts)

Singh. Henry Havelock and Henry Lawrence died
during a siege in this event that also saw the Storming of Secundra Bagh and the
siege of (10 pts)

Lucknow. It began after a rumor that the new Enfield Rifles were being lubricated
with cow and pig fat. For ten points, name this 1857 Indian rebellion against Great Britiain.

(30 pts) This event ended the Peace of Saint-Germain-en-Laye. Pope Gregory XIII sent a Golden
Rose to Charles IX in commemoration of this event, which saw Charles Danowitz kill
Admiral (20 pts)

Gaspard de Coligny. It took place in the aftermath of the marriage between
Margaret of Valois and (10 pts)

Henry III of Navarre and was instigated by either Henry of Guise or
Catherine de Medici. For ten points, name this 1572 massacre of Huguenots.

(30 pts) This battle’s highest ranking English casualty was Edward, Duke of York. The Siege of
Harfleur preceded this battle, whose losers raided an enemy (20 pts)

baggage train, causing
the winning commander to order prisoner executions. One side in this battle drove sharp
wooden stakes in front of their position; heavy rain then trapped (10 pts)

Charles d’Albret’s cavalry
in deep mud at the mercy of massed English longbows. For ten points, name this 1415 battle of the
Hundred Years War, a victory for Henry V.

(30 pts) Operation Harvest Festival was this event’s largest single action. The Einsatzgruppen
were used to carry out this event. At the Wannsee Conference [VAHN-zay Conference],
it was proposed that (20 pts)

Scandinavia would not be subject to this event, and ferries to
Sweden thus protected many Danes from it. The Nuremberg (10 pts)

Trials prosecuted many
planners of this event, which was described as the Final Solution. Dachau and Auschwitz were sites of
concentration camps during, for ten points, what genocide of Jews and other “undesirables” by Nazi
Germany during World War II?

(30 pts) This leader was promoted to Field Marshal after the Battle of Lodz and succeeded
Friedrich Ebert in his highest post. This man, who named a defensive line set up after the
Battle of the (20 pts)

Somme, teamed up with Erich Ludendorff to win the Battle of Tannenberg
during World War I. This man was elected President of the (10 pts)

Weimar Republic in 1925,
narrowly defeating Hitler. For ten points, name this German general and statesman who was honored as
the namesake of an airship that, in 1937, exploded over New Jersey.
